0.title: Audio Offers Gruesome Details of Jamal Khashoggi Killing, Turkish Official Says
0.abstract: The Saudi journalist’s fingers were severed and he was later beheaded, according to details from audio recordings published in the Turkish media.

1.title: In Afghanistan’s Season of Crisis, ‘Words Do Not Have the Strength’
1.abstract: Seventeen years into the war, Afghans cannot remember a time quite like this, with peril and hopelessness at every turn, and no clear way out.

2.title: Brazil’s Bitter Presidential Race Leads to Scores of Assaults
2.abstract: The country is divided between a far-right candidate who advocates fighting violence with violence, and a leftist rival. The increasing animosity has led to more than 70 attacks on political opponents.

3.title: Theresa May Plays for Time on Brexit, Amid Talk of an Extension
3.abstract: At a summit Mrs. May asked for help in reviving stalled exit talks, but offered little new. Negotiations now look likely to go down to the wire.

4.title: Japan’s Cherry Blossoms (Some of Them) Appear Months Early
4.abstract: An unusually strong typhoon season may have caused the famously picturesque flowers to bloom long before April, when they typically emerge.

5.title: U.S. Spy Agencies Are Increasingly Convinced of Saudi Prince’s Ties to Journalist’s Disappearance
5.abstract: American intelligence officials have growing circumstantial evidence of Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman’s involvement in Jamal Khashoggi’s disappearance in Istanbul.

6.title: Legalizing Recreational Marijuana, Canada Begins a National Experiment
6.abstract: On Wednesday, Canada becomes the first major world economy to legalize recreational marijuana, presenting the country with enormous public policy challenges.

7.title: Afghan Leader Blindsided by U.S. Meeting With Taliban, Officials Say
7.abstract: An American envoy who met the Taliban reportedly tried to evade the topic during a meeting with an already concerned Afghan president, several officials say.

8.title: How One Journalist’s Death Provoked a Backlash That Thousands Dead in Yemen Did Not
8.abstract: The sudden turn against Saudi Arabia reveals uncomfortable realities of alliance politics, group psychology and the perception of morality.

9.title: Afghan Police Chief in Kandahar Is Killed After Meeting With U.S. Commander
9.abstract: Gen. Abdul Raziq had survived dozens of attempts on his life before the attack on Thursday. Gen. Austin S. Miller, the commander of American forces in Afghanistan, was not hurt.

10.title: Jim Mattis, Meeting His Chinese Counterpart, Tries to Ease Tensions
10.abstract: The defense secretary moved to sand down sharp edges of the relationship after Vice President Mike Pence gave a pointed critique of Beijing.

11.title: Saudi Journalist, Midterms, DNA: Your Wednesday Evening Briefing
11.abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.

12.title: U.S. Bars American Aid Groups From Traveling to North Korea
12.abstract: The move comes as the Trump administration seeks to tighten sanctions as part of its maximum-pressure campaign during nuclear negotiations.

13.title: Overlooked No More: Yamei Kin, the Chinese Doctor Who Introduced Tofu to the West
13.abstract: Long before veggie burgers and soy lattes were fashionable, Kin was sent on a mission by the United States government to uncover the benefits of the soybean to Americans.

14.title: The Skywhale Returns to Australia’s Skies, and Its Creator Braces for Impact
14.abstract: The buxom hot-air balloon was widely condemned when it first appeared five years ago. The artist who created it is hoping for a warmer reception this time.

15.title: Ebola Outbreak in Congo Not a Global Emergency, W.H.O. Says
15.abstract: Health officials expressed serious concern about the disease, which has a high risk of spreading to neighbors, but were optimistic it would be controlled.

16.title: U.N. Syria Envoy, Staffan de Mistura, Announces Resignation
16.abstract: Mr. de Mistura, the United Nations chief negotiator for Syria, will be the third diplomat to leave the job since Syria’s grinding civil war began 7 years ago.

17.title: The Legal Cannabis Experiment Begins: The Canada Letter
17.abstract: A special edition of the Canada Letter looks at the day marijuana became legal.

18.title: A Top Indian Minister Resigns, but Can #MeToo Reform Government?
18.abstract: India’s governing party promised to champion women and economic growth, but more women are leaving the work force than ever, partly over safety concerns.

19.title: Istanbul Vending Machines Offer Subway Credit for Recycled Bottles and Cans
19.abstract: The city has installed “reverse vending machines” at metro stations that crush, shred and sort the materials as a way of paying for travel.

20.title: Queensland Becomes Latest Australian State to Decriminalize Abortion
20.abstract: After days of emotional debate, lawmakers overturned an 1899 law that made abortion a criminal offense. “History has been made,” the premier said.

21.title: Mother Mushroom, Vietnamese Activist, Is Said to Be Released
21.abstract: The blogger, whose real name is Nguyen Ngoc Nhu Quynh, was freed to fly to the U.S. as Defense Secretary Jim Mattis was visiting, rights groups said.

22.title: China Imposes Record Fine on Vaccine Maker Over Safety Scandal
22.abstract: The penalty, of $1.3 billion, comes at a time of increasing anxieties among the country’s middle class, already furious about a spate of drug and food safety scandals.

23.title: Student Gunman Kills 19 and Wounds Dozens at a College in Crimea
23.abstract: The lone attacker detonated an explosive device, then opened fire at his classmates, in the deadliest school assault in Russia since the Beslan massacre in 2004.

24.title: Mike Pompeo Meets Turkish President to Discuss Saudi Journalist’s Fate
24.abstract: President Trump said the United States had asked Turkish officials for what they say are recordings of the gruesome killing of Jamal Khashoggi by Saudi agents.

25.title: What’s at Stake in Brazil’s Election? The Future of the Amazon
25.abstract: The next president of Brazil may shape the destiny of the Amazon, which is vital to reining in climate change. The stakes for the planet are huge.

26.title: Ian Kiernan, Australian Sailor Who Battled Pollution, Dies at 78
26.abstract: Appalled by the trash he saw in the world’s oceans, he began a cleanup campaign in Sydney that went global.

27.title: Israel Strikes Gaza After a Rocket Is Fired
27.abstract: The main militant groups in Gaza, including Hamas and Islamic Jihad, issued a joint statement denying responsibility for the rocket fire against Israel.

28.title: South Korea Denies Refugee Status to Hundreds of Fleeing Yemenis
28.abstract: The arrival of the refugees from the war-torn country ignited a backlash in South Korea, fueling the country’s first anti-asylum movement.

29.title: Saudi Arabia Delivers $100 Million Pledged to U.S. as Pompeo Lands in Riyadh
29.abstract: The funds, earmarked for aid to Syria, arrived as Secretary of State Mike Pompeo visited the kingdom to discuss the fate of a missing Saudi dissident.

30.title: A K.K.K. Endorsement? No Thanks, Says Brazil’s Top Presidential Candidate
30.abstract: “He sounds like us,” David Duke, a former grand wizard, said of Jair Bolsonaro, the far-right candidate. “Enormous stupidity!” Mr. Bolsonaro responded.

31.title: The Jamal Khashoggi Case: Suspects Had Ties to Saudi Crown Prince
31.abstract: Links between Prince Mohammed and at least four suspects in the disappearance of Jamal Khashoggi may make it harder to advance a “rogue killers” explanation.

32.title: Pompeo, Politics, Charlottesville: Your Tuesday Evening Briefing
32.abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.

33.title: U.S. Military Airstrike Kills 60 Shabab Fighters in Somalia
33.abstract: The military said the strike, which followed attacks on Somali security forces and their American advisers, was the deadliest against the extremist group in nearly a year.

34.title: Anna Burns Wins the Man Booker Prize for ‘Milkman’
34.abstract: The judges cited her use of dark humor to explore tribalism, state-sponsored terrorism, social division and sexual and political oppression.

35.title: We Want to Hear Your Family’s Stories From World War I
35.abstract: We’re asking readers to tell us about their family members who served during World War I.

36.title: Embattled Macron Shuffles French Cabinet, Again, in Favor of Loyalists
36.abstract: The French president chose Christophe Castaner, who once declared “an aspect of love” in their relationship, to take over the Interior Ministry.

37.title: We’re Covering Heritage Sites Threatened by Climate Change. The List Just Got Longer.
37.abstract: A new study says some of the most important ancient places in the Mediterranean might not survive global warming.
